Message.Title: P/E does not matter with AMZN. History of P/E.
Message.Msg: P/E matters only to dividend paying companies' stocks, when dividend yield is important to prospective investors. To non-dividend paying stocks, it means nothing. And AMZN is a proud member of non-dividend paying stocks.

Topic.Title: can someone here state an opinion without bashing? I am short lnkd currently deep in the red :(

Message.Msg: Linked in is one that the Hedge Funds love, like this one. They don't make any money, but they keep growing and you are right, the valuations don't make any sense, but that doesn't mean anything except you can be right and lose all of your money long before the markets become rational. I would suggest from now on when you go short or long a stock, you decide before you make the trade, what you are willing to lose on the trade and if it goes against you, you are stopped out and your losses are limited. One of the biggest mistakes people make is not making those kinds of decisions and sticking to them.

Topic.Title: EPS IS NEGATIVE, HOW COULD THIS BE?

Message.Msg: Look at their free cash flow rather than earnings per share. http://finance.yahoo.com/q/cf?s=AMZN&annual. The amount of cash on their balance sheet (the amount in their checking accounts) just keeps increasing due to depreciation and revenues that are constantly growing. It's actually better to not earn anything, while creating immense free cash, because they never have to pay taxes. That's why it keeps going up.

Topic.Title: Amazon Has No Competition

Message.Msg: I am buying here because I buy a little more stock every quarter, and Amazon is no more expensive than it was when it was $30 per share, or $60 per share. The fact is that Amazon has always been a expensive stock if you look at it strictly on a PE basis. People don't understand the Amazon business model and that has been and continues to be to reinvest in it's ecosystem. And it makes even more sense now because capital is cheap, and as long as capital is cheap it makes more sense to invest back in the business than it is to keep giant amounts of cash on the balance sheet because cash isn't going to earn a lot of money now anyway. Amazon's revenues are growing 10's of billions yearly, nobody delivers just about any product faster, and nobody has better service. Strong buy........$500/share coming.

Topic.Title: Earnings don't matter

Message.Msg: "What happens when sales are decelerating and margins don't ultimately expand?" If sales were to decline, and margins not expand, I'd be real concerned as an Amazon long. However, for the last 10 years, the SMALLEST yoy annual increase has been 23%, in 2005. Here's the article: http://seekingalpha.com/article/1156871-why-amazon-s-share-price-will-keep-rising?source=email_rt_article_readmore

Topic.Title: Earnings don't matter

Message.Msg: Hi Bruce, I saw your article. I think you did a nice job in writing it and you make a bull case but really it did not convince me in any way and quite frankly I am in the green on the short side of AMZN. Granted I have only shorted the stock when I thought it was excessively high, which is probably a misnomer but which it has been recently. I also took advantage of the stock being bid up after hours on what I considered to be a weak revenue and weak guidance given the recent run-up the stock had. If I remember correctly guidance for the next quarter represents an average 20% or just under. I would pay close attention to where they come in. The stock cannot get too far ahead of itself and then miss on the top and bottom-lines and guide down, that will ultimately get a high flyer a haircut every time no matter how many analysts try to lead the sheep to slaughter with higher price targets (Wall Street at it's finest!). Good luck, I hope the stock gives you a nice reentry level for adding. I'm sure I'll be exiting before that level.

Topic.Title: Earnings don't matter

Message.Msg: Bruce: Did you add today? I did. Amazon's 1P growth rate is below that now (and trending lower because of sales tax and competitive developments)...3P growth does not provide the same net margins (still waiting for one of the analysts to compare the net profit per item sold on a 3P versus 1P basis and still conclude that the shift to 3P is beneficial to Amazon rather than a means to preserve value once it has to collect sales tax everywhere on 1P)... In a year, when Amazon is down at $100, everyone will look back at this January and wonder what happened. What happened is technical trading and option algos gone amiss breaking the entire market.

Message.Title: Bad News and Good News for Shorts.
Message.Msg: 1. Bad news: Nikkei up 333.65 (3.02%). 2. Good news: Nikkei and the DOW often move in opposite directions. So the DOW could drop ` tomorrow. 3. Bad news: The DOW and AMZN often move in opposite directions. So, tomorrow, the DOW could drop and AMZN could shoot up sharply. Hooah!

Topic.Title: Bad News and Good News for Shorts.

Topic.Title: can someone explain this to me or give an opinion?? ITS on lnkd before the earnings on thursday

Message.Msg: Remember, in the new normal of investing, one wants losses not profits. Those get taxed and effective rates will be heading up. Never mind the fact that effective tax rates will continue to increase into the future. In reality, inflation + increasing effective taxes should lead to multiple compression. But, we cannot be constrained to reality until every short is killed. Of course, by that point we will have already crossed the event horizon and it won't matter anymore...
